channel.title: construction on Relay Computer
channel.description: Recent content in construction on Relay Computer

item.title: Decoder Construction
item.description: In my last post I covered off the full design for the decoder card so all that remains is to get it soldered up and tested.

item.title: Controller Construction
item.description: In my last couple of posts I covered off the full design for the controller unit. As the PCBs have now arrived I can get on with soldering up the cards and giving them a test.

item.title: Sequencer Construction
item.description: In my last couple of posts I covered off the full design for the sequencer unit. With PCBs now safely arrived in the post I can get on with soldering up the cards and giving them a test.

item.title: Making a PCB
item.description: After years of using pad/prototyping boards to build my computer I’ve decided to switch things up a bit and have a go at making a custom PCB.

item.title: Auxiliary Control Construction
item.description: In my last three posts I covered the design of the auxiliary control unit which will ease entering and inspecting programs in the computer’s memory. With the design ‘in the bag’ it’s time to get constructing although this time we’re not starting with a blank card …

item.title: Incrementer Construction (Part 1 of 2)
item.description: We’re getting nearer and nearer to a computer that can run though a program in memory rather than just a single instruction … we’ve got memory to hold the program and a program counter to point to the current instruction in memory.

item.title: Memory Construction (Part 2 of 2)
item.description: In my last post I made a start on the memory unit construction with the lower memory card. The lower card centres around the memory IC which runs at 5V.

item.title: Memory Construction (Part 1 of 2)
item.description: It’s time to make a start on the construction of the memory unit and as mentioned in my last post this one is a bit more complex than ‘boring old registers’ and so I’ll split it over two posts.

item.title: Program Counter Construction
item.description: In my last couple of posts I’ve been slightly distracted by some ‘miscellany’ but now I return to form and crack on with constructing the program counter.

item.title: Miscellany Special: Backplane X, Cable Routing and Address Bus
item.description: Continuing on with the theme from my last post … here is another ‘miscellany special’ covering all the little ‘side jobs’ I’ve been doing on my relay computer alongside the primary work of constructing the Program Counter, Memory and Incrementer cards.

item.title: Miscellany Special: Power Distribution
item.description: Having somehow forgotten to take time off work I’m now playing ‘annual leave catch up’ which means lots of four day weeks but also, and more importantly for this blog, I’m getting time to crack on with construction of my relay computer.

item.title: More Laser Cut Parts
item.description: I’ve nearly got the design for the memory cards done and ready to share but once that’s out the way it’ll be time to get on with some construction again.

item.title: W Backplane Construction & Power Distribution
item.description: Before I can test the new decoder, sequencer and controller cards all working together with the rest of the computer I need to construct the ‘W’ backplane which the new cards sit on.

item.title: User Interface Construction: Instruction, Clock and Sequencer
item.description: Well, the good news is I’ve just passed a major milestone in constructing this relay computer … it can now perform a single instruction in full firing the various control lines as needed.

item.title: Controller Construction: MOV-8, ALU and SETAB
item.description: So yea, it’s been a while since my last post … in fact it’s been just over six months. For some reason I decided I didn’t have enough to do in the evenings so had a crack at becoming an actuary.

item.title: Sequencer Construction: 8-cycle FSM
item.description: I’m just about at the half way mark now for getting the computer to operate the MOV8, ALU and SETAB instructions. The easier cards are out of the way now … time for the slightly more complex ones.

item.title: Decoder Construction: MOV-8, ALU & SETAB
item.description: In a change from prior form I’m combining the construction and testing of the next card in to a single post this time. Partly because this card is a nice easy one but also because it’s the first card that I’ll be partially constructing to begin with and then I’ll return to it later to add further functionality.

item.title: Register Construction: Instruction Register
item.description: There’s been lots of theory going on in my recent posts but the time for design is over (for now) … it’s time to get constructing.

item.title: New Workbench
item.description: Those who have been reading my posts and watching my videos (you have my sympathy) will know that alongside constructing this computer I’ve also been busy renovating a house I bought almost a year ago.

item.title: User Interface: Display B Initial Design and Construction
item.description: In my last post I put together the beginnings of the first display card … named in a brilliant flash of nomenclature as display card A.

item.title: User Interface: Display A Initial Design and Construction
item.description: Following on from working on the main data switches in my last post this time I’ve taken the first steps in designing and constructing the first of two display cards which will sit in the upper enclosure.

item.title: User Interface: Data Switches
item.description: Now I’ve got a fully working ALU and four registers completed I want to take a short break from card building and turn my attention to making it easier to interact with the computer.

item.title: Register Construction: A and D 8-bit Registers
item.description: I haven’t posted in nearly a month but in between bouts of enjoying the rare British sunshine I’ve been plodding away at the A/D register card and it’s now finally ready for testing.

item.title: Register Construction: B and C 8-bit Registers
item.description: As mentioned in my last post I decided this time around not to post after each stage of card construction (being as the construction steps are now pretty similar to those for previous cards).

item.title: Enclosure Update: Laser Cutting
item.description: I couldn’t resist it any longer … I’ve ordered the laser cut parts for the case doors, sides and bay floor/ceilings. I did say I’d wait for my chosen laser cut website to put out a free delivery offer but I ended up crumbling under the weight of my own impatience.

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Backplane
item.description: In my last post I mentioned I’d suffered a bit of a set back with the construction of the ALU backplane. Well, the short version of things is that I’ve admitted defeat and constructed a new backplane using a different design … it looks like this:

item.title: Enclosure Initial Construction
item.description: I’ve been promising this post for quite a while now … an update on how the enclosure construction is going. Well, it’s very good thanks :)

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Control Card Full Test
ALU Construction: Control Card Power Rails & Wire Wrap
item.description: I’ve been a bit short of time lately so I’ve been working on the ALU Control Card in little bursts … but after lots of these little bursts I’ve now got all the power rails and wire wrap done for this card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Control Card Header Pins & Relay Sockets
item.description: Following on from the first two successfully completed ALU cards, for logic and arithmetic, it’s time to make a start on the control card (well, actually, the LEDs and connectors are already done from earlier but you get the gist).

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Arithmetic Card Full Test
ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Wire Wrap 2
item.description: I’ve managed to squeeze in a couple more wire wrapping sessions this week so in this post there’s a few photos of progress so far.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Wire Wrap 1
item.description: Fear not (just in case you were for some reason) all this talk of Sketchup and enclosures and so on hasn’t totally diverted me from the main task of constructing the ALU.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Power Rails
item.description: Another round of soldering done … this time putting down the power rails on the arithmetic card along with some soldered wire links. This is the last of the soldering for this card - it’s all wire wrapping form hereon in.

item.title: ALU Construction: 1-bit Arithmetic Full Construction
item.description: So, as mentioned in my last post this time I’ve put in the wire links and wraps needed to test the first bit of the arithmetic card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Relay Sockets
item.description: It’s always a fiddly job getting the relay sockets soldered in and the ALU arithmetic card proved no exception. With this in mind I’ve been spreading the work out over several mini sessions in accordance with my new post-Xmas lack of patience.

item.title: ALU Construction: Arithmetic Card Header Pins
item.description: Following on from the successful construction of the ALU logic card in my last post it’s time to start off the new year with the next ALU card (number 2 of 3 ALU cards in total) … the arithmetic card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Completed Logic Card Full Test
item.description: The ALU logic card is now finally complete! … well, it is now I’ve popped the last few relays into their sockets. The final card looks like this:

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Wrap 3
item.description: I’m now just one session of wire wrapping away from a completed ALU logic card. The final job is to wire up the gating relays that select one of the five logic results back on to the data bus.

item.title: ALU Construction: 8-bit Logic Unit Tests
item.description: There’s now enough sockets, solder and wires to test all eight bits of the ALU logic card. This isn’t quite a full test as the gating relays that apply one of the results produced by each bit unit haven’t been wired up yet but there’s enough there to be able to set an input and see the results displayed on the LEDs along the front of the card.

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Wrap 2
item.description: Continuing on with the wire wrapping for the ALU logic card next up is the input and result links: {% figure %} {% endfigure %}

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Wrap 1
item.description: Finally, with all the soldering now done, it’s time to set about wire wrapping the ALU logic card. First up is the internal connections within each logic bit:

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Power Rails
item.description: It seems that every time I move on to the next stage of construction on the ALU logic card it’s fiddlier than the stage before it … this stage is no exception.

item.title: Test Board: Construction
item.description: I’ve just realised that as I’ve been constructing the first ALU card I’ve not given much thought to how I’ll actually test the card (or other cards for that matter) when complete … this post therefore represents a quick aside to tackle testing.

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Relay Sockets
item.description: The construction of the ALU logic card is coming along nicely but there’s still a lot of soldering ahead to get all the relay sockets down … and this part is the fiddliest bit yet.

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Header Pins
item.description: Following on from the successful construction of the first bit on the ALU logic card in my last post it’s now time to start putting together the other 7 bits and the gating circuits (to place one of the logic results on to the data bus).

item.title: ALU Construction: 1-bit Logic Full Construction
item.description: So, although I probably should construct the logic card methodically a full stage at a time (solder header pins then sockets then wire wrap) I can’t resist fully assembling a single bit alone to see if/how it works.

item.title: ALU Construction: LED Tests
item.description: Following on from my last post I can now test the LEDs that have been soldered and hooked up to the header pins on each of the three ALU cards (Logic, Arithmetic and Control).

item.title: ALU Construction: Logic Card Wire Links
item.description: Before I can test all of the LEDs laid down so far (to make sure they survived the heat of the soldering iron) I need to add some wire links on the logic card between the LED anodes and the header pins.

item.title: ALU Construction: LED Header Pins
item.description: So far, in the construction of the three ALU cards (Logic, Arithmetic and Control) I’ve soldered down the connectors and LEDs. It’s now time to solder in some header pins and join them to the existing connectors and LEDs ready for wire-wrapping later.

item.title: Backplane Design and Construction
item.description: Originally when I was thinking about how I’d connect up the various cards of this computer I had ribbon cables in mind. Ribbon cables are straightforward to use and physically flexible which would

item.title: ALU Construction: Connectors and LEDs
item.description: As promised in my last post it’s finally time to get the soldering iron out and make a start on constructing the three cards that make up the ALU.
